In particular, the default argument is to use GPU 0 (from [train_cifar10.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_cifar10.py#L12) and other examples): 

```
parser.add_argument('--gpus', type=str, default='0', help='the gpus will be used, e.g "0,1,2,3"')
```

Perhaps we should change the default usage to `NoneType`? i.e:

```
parser.add_argument('--gpus', type=str, default=None, help='the gpus will be used, e.g "0,1,2,3"')
```
mx.io.resizeiter

You can do it in the submodule ps-lite.
However, we find it not necessary for gpu training. Sync SGD works best for less than a couple hundred gpu machines

But it does confuse. You may change it like what `train_mnist.py` does.

@piiswrong @thirdwing My problem is still exist, related #2617

I tested consistency between cpu and cudnn implementation:

``` Python
def test_batchnorm_with_type():
    sym = mx.sym.BatchNorm(name='norm', fix_gamma=False)
    ctx_list = [{'ctx': mx.gpu(0), 'norm_data': (10, 2, 10, 10), 'type_dict': {'norm_data': np.float32}},
                {'ctx': mx.cpu(0), 'norm_data': (10, 2, 10, 10), 'type_dict': {'norm_data': np.float32}}]
    check_consistency(sym, ctx_list)

    sym = mx.sym.BatchNorm(name='norm', fix_gamma=True)
    check_consistency(sym, ctx_list)
```

It passed.

The difference between cudnn v4 and v5 is that with v4 BatchNorm use mxnet's own implementation and CuDNNBatchNorm uses cudnn's implementation. The two have different parameter specs so cannot be used interchangeably.
With cudnn v5 the cudnn implementation is merge in as the default implementation for BatchNorm and CuDNNBatchNorm is deleted.

@piiswrong @pluskid @sbodenstein I'm thinking whether it's necessary to write non-cudnn based RNN symbols in C++. Torch seems to only have included the CuDNN version of LSTM.

@sxjscience Amazing,  the error does not exist in the latest version.  thank you for answering.
p.s: what more shock me is that I just feel depressed there is no operator like nn.MM() in torch this afternoon. when I download the latest version I find it has been supported in latest version. so lucky..

@sxjscience: it would be very convenient to have a C++ version, as this interface will probably be the simplest RNN interface for users (hence quite popular), and it will be very annoying to not be able to evaluate/deploy this on CPU (you would need to insert a complicated computational graph to replicate this). 

Regarding Torch: the Torch cuDNN package only has cuDNN implementations, its up to other packed (like NN) to have non-cuDNN implementations as well. The RNN package is wanting to add a compatible version, at least for LSTM: https://github.com/Element-Research/rnn/issues/239
Can you give me a script to reproduce the error?
I think we can first start with CuDNN version, then add a compatible GPU/CPU code as a second step
what is the status on this PR?
It would be great if one of us can look into it and see if there is a chance for optimized kernel, the kernel from torch might be a good reference

I understand that logic, but it makes sense to standardise the examples, as well as allowing CPU only users to a least try them for one epoch should they wish. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2626

@tqchen: yes, it would also make writing a cuDNN compatible CPU/GPU version easier having this first.

I should have a first version of the cuDNN symbol by the end of this week.

Hi, @zachmayer really sorry for this late reply.

I think you are correct and mxnet is also correct.

During the training, the rmse is calculated in a batch and take average. In your case, the size of training and validation set is not divisible by the batch size, so the result might be slightly different.

Can you try the code below? I just change the batch size and now you should get consistent rsme.

``` r
require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)
data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")

train.ind <- sample(1:506, 253)
train.x <- data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y <- BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x <- data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y <- BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]

data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)

mx.callback.trueerror <- function(period=1) {
  function(iteration, nbatch, env, verbose) {
    if (iteration %% period == 0) {
      p1 <- predict(env$model, test.x, array.layout='rowmajor')[1,]
      if(verbose) cat(paste("True Validation-rmse:", sqrt(mean((p1 - test.y)^2))))
    }
    return(TRUE)
  }
}

mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(
  lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
  ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=253,
  learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
  eval.data = list(data=test.x, label=test.y),
  epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.trueerror(1)
)
```

Hi, @gpierard sorry for the late reply. I think you are correct on this point.

The RSME is calculated in each batch and taken the average during the training.
what's the results from print param?
It's a symbol that can be indexed just like an array.

Somehow your gammas are not fixed at one during training with previous versions of the code.
Instead of modifying the code, you can load the model parameters, set *_gamma to 1 and write it back with mx.model.load_checkpoint and mx.model.save_checkpoint.

All models trained and tested with the newest code shouldn't have this problem

I think the function you are looking for is `mxnet:::mx.model.train()`.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/model.R#L94

This is not exported.

there should be a mx.model.load_checkpoint

@topepo Really sorry for the late reply.

You got different results because you are building two different networks. I think the code below will give you the same results.

``` r
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
act <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, act_type='tanh')
fc <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc)

mx.set.seed(1)
model1 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro, 
                                      X=train.x, y=train.y,
                                      ctx=mx.cpu(), 
                                      num.round=50, 
                                      array.batch.size=20,
                                      learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9, 
                                      eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse)

###
mx.set.seed(1)
model2 <- mx.mlp(data = train.x, 
                 label = train.y,
                 hidden_node = 1,
                 out_node = 1, 
                 out_activation = "rmse", 
                 learning.rate = 2e-6, 
                 momentum = 0.9, 
                 eval.metric = mx.metric.rmse, 
                 array.layout = "rowmajor",
                 num.round=50, array.batch.size=20)
```

I think there are two problems.

First, in the line

```
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc3)
```

`fc3` is not defined.

Second, please try different data.

I am trying to iterate the elements based on what you said. But I received an error when I tried to visualize the network. The code is as follows:

```
import mxnet as mx
net = mx.symbol.Variable("data")
net = mx.symbol.SliceChannel(net, num_outputs=3, name="sliced")
groups = []
for i in range(2):
    temp = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(net[i], num_hidden=2)
    groups.append(temp)
final_output = mx.symbol.Group(groups)

a = mx.viz.plot_network(final_output, shape={"data":(1, 3)}, node_attrs={"shape":'rect',"fixedsize":'false'})
a.render(view=True)
```

The error says " 

```
shape = shape_dict[key][1:]
KeyError: u'sliced_output
```

Is there anything wrong here?

Also when I used list_outputs() to see the names of output blocks, I found the name system was strange. If the number of channel is less than 10, the name is normal like "sliced_output0, sliced_output1 etc.". When it is bigger than 10, it becomes like "sliced_output:, sliced_output;" or even "sliced_outputA". It seems based on ASCII. Is the error due to this issue?
